awd_titl_txt: EAPSI:Form and Function of the Gibbon Cervical Spine
awd_abstract_narration:
Habitual bipedal locomotion distinguishes the human lineage from that of all other primates. How the head and neck responded to this radical change in mode of locomotion remains understudied. The neck functions in two critical ways: it stabilizes and mobilizes the head. This study will attempt to understand how the shape of bones composing the neck (i.e. cervical vertebrae) is adapted to these functions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Drs. Hiroo Kumakura and Ryosuke Goto at the University of Osaka, who possess the unique combination of equipment, expertise, and access to live primates to be ideal mentors on this research. Elucidating the relationship between vertebral form and neck function will facilitate understanding the postural behavior of fossil species. More broadly, results of this study can be used to evaluate the appropriateness of using non-human primates as proxies for humans in spinal injury research.

A gibbon (Hylobates lar) will be filmed during habitual locomotion with head and neck movement evaluated using motion analysis software. Mobility will be measured using radiographs of its maximum range of head-neck movement. These functional measures of posture and mobility will be related to specific aspects of cervical vertebral form. Form-function relationships established here will be used to understand the adaptations of the primate cervical spine as well as retrodict the behaviors of fossil specimens based on preserved morphology. This project will further the understanding of the functional morphology of the cervical spine, its relationship to locomotor diversification within the hominoid clade, and the mosaic evolution of hominin bipedal locomotion. The NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Japanese Society for the Promotion of Science.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project was to understand the form and function of the gibbon (Hylobates lar) cervical spine. The neck functions in two critical ways: it maintains postural stability during locomotion and allows for a mobile visual field. This study tested the hypotheses that the form of the neck bones (i.e. cervical vertebrae) and neck musculature are adapted to maintaining posture during locomotion as well as head and neck mobility. The hypotheses were tested through three distinct projects: a kinematic study, a range of motion study, and a dissection study.

Kinematic results demonstrate that the type of locomotion employed affects how head stability is maintained. The head, neck, and trunk moved differently in bipedal walking than in swinging (brachiation). This has important implications for understanding how the cervical spine is adapted to many modes of locomotion and will inform both my thesis and other future research. Results show weak support for the relationship between range of motion and cervical morphology within the gibbon cervical spine. It is likely that a broader pattern will be elucidated through interspecific comparisons. This study was presented at the American Association of Anatomists’ Meetings in March (2016). Despite the similarity in neck position, results show differences in muscular anatomy due to trunk posture. This study was presented at the American Association of Physical Anthropologists’ Meetings in April (2016). Additionally, data from the third project will be incorporated into my thesis.           

The neck is a poorly studied are of research. As such, the functional influences on the cervical spine are not understood. This research showed that intervertebral range of motion is not influenced by the morphology of individual vertebrae. Meaning, there is very little relationship between form and function at the vertebral level. It is likely that the differences are too minute to show a pattern and a whole-neck approach is necessary. The thesis incorporating multiple species will likely prove more successful. The results also demonstrate differences in neck musculature due to variations in trunk posture. Understanding muscular differences can inform the functional morphology of the skeletal structures they attach to and further our knowledge of the biomechanics of head stability. The results of the research demonstrate that the mode of locomotion does affect the function of the cervical spine. This has informed the experimental methods of my thesis. Because most primates habitually practice more than one mode of locomotion, how the frequency of these practices influence vertebral morphology needs to be further investigated.

Furthermore, these results will be incorporated into my thesis which is studying he relationship between upright neck posture and bipedal locomotion has yet to be established, but their co-occurrence in humans has led researchers to assume a connection. Attempts to understand this evolutionary change have focused on other aspects of skeletal anatomy, such as the pelvis and lumbar spine. Preserved early hominin cervical vertebrae present an ‘ape-like’ morphology. The thesis project aims to understand that morphology in the context of neck function during locomotion and its evolution within the hominin lineage. 

Functional relationships established by the proposed research are relevant to both anthropological and medical fields. Spine research often uses nonhuman primates as models for spinal injury and treatment without understanding functional differences between humans and other primates. This study will have implications for the appropriateness of these non-human primates in medical research. This lab-based study is also a vital step towards conducting field-based inv...

Preserved early hominin cervical vertebrae present an æape-likeÆ morphology. Functional relationships established by the proposed research are relevant to both anthropological and medical fields. Spine research often uses nonhuman primates as models for spinal injury and treatment without understanding functional differences between humans and other primates. This study will have implications for the appropriateness of these non-human primates in medical research. This lab-based study is also a vital step towards conducting field-based investigations into the positional behaviors of wild primates.
